div.head: 2.Cor.5.19.2.Cor.5.19. in the Christian Bible is the verse "that God was reconciling the world to himself in Christ, not counting people√≠s sins against them. And he has committed to us the message of reconciliation" (English Standard Version. Bible Gateway) God was in Christ Reconciling the World to Himself
div.author: Katherine Philips

lg.l: When God, contracted a "contract", indicating a formal obligationto Humanity,
Could sigh and suffer, could be sick and die;
When all the heap of Miracles combin'd
To form the greatest, which was, save MankindSaving Mankind as being the "greatest Miracle", indicating authorial commentary on the state on mankind:
Then God took stand in Christ, studying a way
How to repair the Ruin'd World's decayagain, the authorial language -- "decay", indicating something that was once new has now rotted; a loss of quality.
His Love, Pow'r, Wisdom, must some mean procure
His Mercy to advance, Justice secure:
And since Man in Misery was hurl'd"hurl'd" suggests forceful, nonwilling movement-- a potential reference to Adam and Eve ("Man") being hurled from the Garden of Eden into the world ("Misery"),
It cost him more to save then make the World.
Oh! what a desp'rate load of sins had we"We" -- speaker is not passive, but rather identifies as part of humanity,
When God must plot for our Felicity?
When God must beg usRelationship dynamic of humans as being their own downfall, with God in the position of savior that he may forgive,
And dye himselfEmphasis on God as giving -- God creates earth and man, then dies for man before Mankind could live?
And what still are we, when our KingGod as sovereign ruler--a very literal translation of the "divine ruler" connotation of king(?) in vain
Begs his lost Rebels to be Friends again?
What flouds of Love proceed from Heaven's smile,
At once to pardon and to reconcile?
What God himself hath made he cannot hate,
For 'tis one act to Love and to Create:Characterization of God as ultimately giving--despite Philips repeating how humanity is damning itself, God is never portrayed as upset, only understanding
And he's too perfect full of Majesty,
To need additions from our Misery.Establishes human state as Misery (also, line 9, "since Man in Misery was hurl'd")

He hath a Father's, not a Tyrant's, References God as "our King" and "a Father", but removes negative connotations (not a "Tyrant")-- portrays God as being in a natural, uncontested position of power joy;
Shews more his Pow'r to save, than to destroy.
Did there ten thousand Worlds to ruine fall,
One God could save, one Christ redeem them all.
Be silent then, ye narrow Soulds, take heed
Left you restrain the MercyAgain, humans as self-sabotaging -- they will need "Mercy", but might prevent themselves from achieving it by their own actions against God you will need.
But, O my Soul, from these be different,
Imitate thou a nobler Precedent:precedent: an earlier event or action that is regarded as an example or guide to be considered in subsequent similar circumstances (Dictionary.com)
As God with open Arms the World does woo,
Learn thou like God to be enlarged too;
As he begs thy consent to pardon thee,"consent" and "pardon" indicates procedure (plus line 1, "contract") -- that humans must consent to their own salvation
Learn to submit unto thy Enemy;"thy Enemy" as God
As he stands ready thee to entertain,
Be thou as forward to return again;

As he was Crucify'd for thee and by theeThe speaker emphasizes that humans are their own downfall through their sin. Despite this, it was humanity's "sin" of disbelief and hate that led to the crucifition of Jesus, which in turn led to the pardoning of all human sin. In this instance, did humanity's sin prompt their own salvation? Is the speaker indicating that sin is so integrally human that God accounted for sin as the tool to provoking humanity's salvation through Jesus's murder?
Crucifie thou what caus'd his Agony;
lg.note: Speaker ends with a suggestion to the audience--a "moral" poem, as it were
lg.l: And like to him be mortify'd to sin,
Die to the World as he dy'd for it then.
